donationDescription: We have two young girls who have never ridden a bike before. We would like to get two bikes to have our daughters experience how to ride a bike, and partly the things children experience when young.

I am seven months pregnant and will be welcoming my first child this coming September. My husband and I want to be as prepared for our baby as possible, and diapers and a car seat are absolute necessities. Thank you for your support.
I am a 15 year old girl who is in love with photography, but I can’t afford to buy my own camera or ask my parents for one. I would be very happy to keep pursuing my love for photography.

I am a single mother with two daughters. These clothes are for my oldest daughter of 3. I would be very blessed to have any extra clothes for her since the few clothes she has does not fit her anymore, and I don’t have much money to buy her new clothes.
I am usually cooking in the kitchen when I’m not at work to provide food for my family. It would mean a lot to me to have a new blender that works and that lasts long.
Aside from cooking, I am also always baking to keep myself busy. Baking helps me de-stress. By getting a mixer, it will brighten up my own hobby and help me experiment with my culture’s food as well.
I am looking out only for my sons, and diapers for my baby would be a great help to not worry about diapers for a while.

I would like to get a new iron because I don’t have one at the moment. It would be really helpful, especially since the one I had broke a while ago, and it would make my life so much easier than depending on the heat of a shower or my friend's iron.
I am a single mother who is looking for a second job. My little girl needs new shoes because she only has one pair. Any shoes would be appreciated, it does not have to be from Target.

I know an air conditioner is a lot to ask for, but it would mean a lot to me if my sons and myself would be able to get an air conditioner for our small apartment. It would be best to have just an air conditioner than many fans since we don’t have much space at home.
We have owned the same microwave for over five years, and would like to get a new microwave that works. We would not ask of this if we did not need it.
For my job, I need black shoes, but the ones I currently have are not comfortable because they’re a size too small. It would mean a lot to me to get black shoes that could last long and that fit me.

Where would you like this order shipped?

Address: 1353 N. Hamlin St. Chicago, IL 60651

Contact info - phone & email: 773-997-9165

donationDescription: I am a single mother who’s looking for a second job. I have two daughters, one is a baby while the other one is 3 years old. I would like to give my daughter something to make her summer better while playing on the sidewalk since I don’t live near a park.
comments: I am a single mother who’s looking for a second job. I have two daughters, one is a baby while the other one is 3 years old. I would like to give my daughter something to make her summer better while playing on the sidewalk since I don’t live near a park.

donationDescription: I was hesitant to ask for a stove because I thought I would not get it. But, because it’s one of the items that I truly need to keep my family afloat, knowing that I don’t have to depend on a broken one, would be a huge relief.

I am a single mother who is looking for a second job. I have two daughters, one is a baby while the other one is 3 years old. At the moment, I can’t afford to buy diapers, and not worrying about having to buy them for a while would be great.

I am a single mother who’s looking for a second job. I have two daughters, one is a baby while the other one is 3 years old. I would like to give my daughter something to make her summer better while playing on the sidewalk since I don’t live near a park.

I am the mother of 3 active children who are out on summer vacation from school.  They are aged 16 months, 4 years and 5 years 7 months. 
We are cooped up in a very small apartment as we have no means of transportation to go anywhere. My husband is working two jobs and is gone for 60-70 hours a week trying to support us all while also still trying to pay off the debt we owe to his sister who helped us get to America,
My friend, God bless her,  has been coming all the way from Maine to get the kids and me to our appointments.  But  that's wearing her out.  One of those appointments was for my driver's license.  I'm happy to report that I earned one!  So now the only obstacle to getting around is to actually have something to drive. 
This  car or any other one in working condition would be a miracle.

donationDescription: On September, 7, 2019, ICE conducted a massive series of raids, rounding up 680 people working in poultry plants throughout Mississippi, making this the largest single workplace raid in one area.  While some workers are still being held in detention, many have been released to await court hearings that will decide their fates.  This may take months or even years. Meanwhile, our hard-working neighbors are unable to seek employment or support their families. The Mississippi Immigrants Rights Alliance is requesting items to stock various food pantries in affected communities. These basic necessities will make a world of difference in the lives of families who have fled violence and poverty for the opportunity to live and work and provide futures for their children.

While some workers are still being held in detention, many have been released to await court hearings that will decide their fates.  This may take months or even years. Meanwhile, our hard-working neighbors are unable to seek employment or support their families. The Mississippi Immigrants Rights Alliance is requesting items to stock various food pantries in affected communities. These basic necessities will make a world of difference in the lives of families who have fled violence and poverty for the opportunity to live and work and provide futures for their children.

donationDescription: Mateo was separated from his mother in the summer of 2018.  He was detained until just recently.  Mateo was reunited with his mother after the federal court order was issued. He has struggled to adjust in school but is doing well now and is supported by his mother who is an advocate for his education. Mateo is in need of a graphing calculator to complete his homework.  He is a high achieving and conscientious student who has been borrowing a school owned calculator for his advanced math class.  However, he is not allowed to bring the calculator home.  In order for him to keep up with his studies, he needs a graphing calculator that he can bring home to complete homework.

donationDescription:
Katherin requests a viola.   Katherin played the viola in El Salvador for more than five years, where she was a good student at the top of her class.  Since coming to the US less than a year ago, Katherin continues to dedicate herself to her studies.   Her new high school has an orchestra, and she wanted to join to have something familiar and comfortable as compared to the challenges of learning English.  However, with no viola available she has had the challenge of trying to learn to play the violin in addition to all the other challenges she has faced.  Having a viola would give Katherin the opportunity to be successful at something she enjoys, while she continues to focus on her academic pursuits.   Of playing the viola, Katherin said “When I play, my heart is happy and free”.  
 
Her orchestra has the opportunity to go to the University of Georgia in November for a concert and additional instruction, and if they do well could be invited back for further opportunities.  She sees this as an opportunity to learn about US colleges and improve her performance at the same time. 
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification. This is the case for Katherin.

donationDescription: These boots will keep the NH migrant farm workers’ feet warm and dry while staying out in the cold for long hours and working in a wet environment.
Working conditions for migrant farm workers are very challenging especially in the winter. Having the proper layering of the upper body is essential.

Most of the workers on the farm don’t actually have a jacket. They just wear layers of sweaters because it is all they have. Receiving a warm winter jacket would making working conditions quite a bit better.
This hard working migrant farm hand loves soccer, and he even plays outside during winter. In the little free time he has, he would appreciate having these shorts to play soccer, his passion!
Working conditions for migrant farm workers are very challenging especially in the winter. Having the proper headgear is essential.
One of the hard working men on the farm is susceptible of getting much colder than the others. This excellent winter jacket would alleviate some of the discomfort for this migrant worker.
Working conditions for migrant farm workers are very challenging especially in the winter. Having the proper headgear is essential.
Winter socks will keep the migrant workers’ feet from getting cold during long working hours out in the barns.

Winter boot for the youngest child of three kids home alone as their sole provider dad who is in detention with ICE, deportation pending and no provider for the kids are readily available to step up to help.
We are trying to keep them together and at home as long as possible and in school.
Weather is getting colder in VA - and they only have sneakers. We appreciate your consideration.

donationDescription: Working conditions for migrant farm workers are very challenging especially in the winter. Having the proper layering of the upper body is essential.

Many farm workers live in one house and don’t have enough bowls in the house which limits them from being able to eat dinner all at the same time. Having additional bowls would mean that the workers would not have to take turns eating.

Wilder came to the United States as an unaccompanied minor from Guatemala. He reunited with his parents and siblings in Alabama after many years of separation. Wilder has dreamed of continuing his education in the United States. In Guatemala, education is free-of-cost for the first 6 years after which families have to pay if their children want to continue. Wilder’s family could not afford to pay for his education and so he was forced to drop out of school. When he arrived in Alabama, the local school refused to accept him because he was 17 years old. Fortunately, he was able to enroll in ESL/GED classes at the local community college. His mother changed her work schedule so she can drive him to class every day. Wilder’s dream is to learn English and get his GED. In order to achieve this goal, he needs a laptop computer for taking notes in class and completing his homework assignments.

donationDescription: Winter socks will keep the migrant workers’ feet from getting cold during long working hours out in the barns.

Catholic Charities Atlanta works with unaccompanied immigration children, which are children who were not accompanied by their parent or legal guardian at the time they entered the United States.   Almost all of our clients are from Central America and speak Spanish, and face a lot of challenges when enrolling in school in the United States due to language and other barriers.   Our clients are often eager to learn English, but need tools for doing so.  Having an English-Spanish dictionary would help as they transition to the school system and begin learning English.

donationDescription: It is a challenge to keep farm worker's hands warm in the winter as they operate machinery and tend to a variety of chores. These winter gloves are versatile and provide a grip on the palm. Having warm gloves to use while working will improve the working conditions significantly.

Juan is a farm worker who lives and works in New Haven, VT.  He has been in Vermont for 3 years, working on various farms in Addison County.  In Spring 2019, he got his GED working with the UVM Extension Service Migrant Education Program (MEP) and volunteer support from Addison Allies Network, Inc. (AAN). His primary interest in getting his GED was so that he could take college classes. Juan is a talented artist and designer. He is interested in learning how to use CAD to enhance his employment opportunities in the future. Again, working with MEP he enrolled in a CAD class in Fall 2019.  He needed computer for this class.  AAN volunteers helped him to purchase an appropriate computer.  Juan paid for the computer. In October during a lightening storm while Juan was working in the barn, lightening struck his trailer home.  The computer was ruined.  He needs a new computer to continue the CAD class and take additional classes.  He'd like to buy a refurbished computer from the same computer store where he got the first computer.  This store can transfer all his files from the ruined computer to the new computer as part of the purchase price.
$225 was donated towards this item.
Veronica found someone to make up the difference. Check was mailed to Addison Allies for $225.00

donationDescription:
This keyboard is requested for a 16 year old from Guatemala who was released from detention in May.  He is attending school and working to learn English.  In his home country, he played piano and sang in a mission church choir every Sunday.  A keyboard would help him maintain a familiar activity while getting accustomed to his new home.  

Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Winter socks will keep the migrant workers’ feet from getting cold during long working hours out in the barns.

Jose and Antonio are from Tobasco, Mexico.  They work on a dairy farm in North Ferrisburg, VT. They work, at minimum, 12 hours a day 6 days a week. They live on the farm where they work which is in rural Vermont, 7.8 miles from the nearest laundromat.  They live in a small trailer on the farm.  Their work in the barn centers around milking and feeding cows and all the cleaning of equipment involved as well as cleaning animal stalls and changing bedding. This is very dirty work requiring several changes of clothing daily so that they can eat and rest in between shifts.  They rely heavily on washing and drying clothes regularly.  Jose is studying for the GED and they both study English language with Addison Allies Network volunteers.  The dryer at their trailer recently broke and they would like to purchase a used reconditioned one at a local thrift store.

donationDescription: I am looking for a reliable car because I am a single parent and am responsible for my son 1/2 the time. I live in New Haven, VT and have to travel 30 miles to Shoreham to pick up my son and to drive him to school from my house.  He lives part time with his mother, who lives in a different town. That is where his school is. I work full time in Middlebury, VT. I earn $2,080 per month and pay rent of $600 a month and expenses - child support- $82/week.  My current car is a 2005 Subaru Forester with over 200,000 miles and cannot be inspected in its current state.  It will not last much longer. I am completely dependent on my car for work and to see my son. There is no public transportation available to me.

donationDescription:
$450.00 has already been raised, only $182.00 left to go!
I am a single refugee mom of 3 children from the Democratic Republic of the Congo. When I was young, I contracted Polio and lost the use of my left leg. Right now, I get around with the combination of a leg brace I have altered to pick up my leg when I walk and a wheelchair. My 9- year old daughter has started school and was accepted to an afterschool program that helps her with homework and provides additional English class. The bus does not provide transportation home from this program so I have been using my wheelchair to go to school and pick her up. It is a long distance to use a regular wheelchair, the streets are steep, and the concrete is uneven. It is very very difficult to get back and forth. Removing my daughter from this program is not an option because I want her to learn as much as she can. An electric mobility chair would allow me to make the journey to pick up my daughter in a much safer and easier way.  

Thank you to a generous donor for reducing this request amount by $100.00!
Facebook Fundraiser - $350.00
recipientUSLocation: Clarkston, GA -  Democratic Republic of Congo

A Safe Passages client, Brian, requests a laptop and compatible printer from HYH.   He is in the 9th grade at a metro Atlanta high school. A laptop and printer would allow Brian to better keep up with his school assignments and help him advance toward his goal of graduating from high school.
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription:
English is a non-phonetic language, which means we do not always say the words as they are written. Even with reading skills, many English language learners are afraid to start speaking because they are not sure how to correctly pronounce new words. This fear of pronunciation can act as a barrier to language acquisition and further isolate children and families as they try to assimilate into their new school or community. 

Inglés Para Latinos is an English language tool made specifically for Spanish speakers. It allows the reader to learn practical English phrases in an innovative way. Each page lists the phonetic Spanish spelling next to the English phrase so that Spanish readers of all ages can be confident in their pronunciation.  This book would be an extremely useful tool for our clients, and could help empower them to seek out and connect to resources within their communities. 

Catholic Charities Atlanta works with unaccompanied immigration children, which are children who were not accompanied by their parent or legal guardian at the time they entered the United States. Almost all of our clients are from Central America and speak Spanish, and lack of English skills can be a huge barrier when attempting to integrate into their new communities.  Our clients are often eager to learn English, but need tools for doing so.

donationDescription:
English is a non-phonetic language, which means we do not always say the words as they are written. Even with reading skills, many English language learners are afraid to start speaking because they are not sure how to correctly pronounce new words. This fear of pronunciation can act as a barrier to language acquisition and further isolate children and families as they try to assimilate into their new school or community. 

Inglés Para Latinos is an English language tool made specifically for Spanish speakers. It allows the reader to learn practical English phrases in an innovative way. Each page lists the phonetic Spanish spelling next to the English phrase so that Spanish readers of all ages can be confident in their pronunciation.  This book would be an extremely useful tool for our clients, and could help empower them to seek out and connect to resources within their communities. 

Catholic Charities Atlanta works with unaccompanied immigration children, which are children who were not accompanied by their parent or legal guardian at the time they entered the United States. Almost all of our clients are from Central America and speak Spanish, and lack of English skills can be a huge barrier when attempting to integrate into their new communities.  Our clients are often eager to learn English, but need tools for doing so.
recipientUSLocation: Atlanta, GA - El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras

donationDescription:
When refugees come to the U.S., they bring with them important documents from overseas, and upon arrival, they are inundated with more papers and mail from public benefits offices, doctors, school along with regular junk mail. For those without English – the majority—keeping track of key documents and providing them when needed is challenging. Papers are lost or misplaced. Staff time is lost too. A solution emerged when one of our recent Burmese arrivals came with their own binder with plastic inserts containing their important documents. Staff recognized how this simple tool is the solution to this nagging problem, a problem that could result in the delay of critical supports. With this request, we look forward to helping our next 10 refugee families stay organized and more involved in their resettlement process.
 
Jewish Family and Community Services runs many programs for refugees and vulnerable immigrants living in Pittsburgh. Our professional team, assisted by interns, AmeriCorps and volunteers, help families transition to their new American home.

He was released from government care to live with an uncle, and misses being a part of his Catholic church band back home.  He requests a guitar to help him connect to his faith and provide a bit of familiarity and comfort as he adjusts to life in a new country. 

Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

itemName: Money Requested  for Elderly and Sick Family in Mexico
donationDescription: Antonio has been in America for 16 years working at various jobs, most recently in the hemp farming industry in Vermont and before that on dairy farms in Vermont for 5 years.  He regularly sends money to his mother, grandmother and grandfather in Mexico.  He sends $100 monthly for food and more for medication.  The family has diabetes and heart problems and require medications regularly. When the pandemic hit, Antonio was laid off from his job.   He starts a new job in a week.  Since he has been laid off, he has not been able to send money home and will need to wait two weeks before he receives a paycheck from the new job. Antonio is very worried about his family, particularly his grandfather who requires several medications.  Funding this request would help tide this family over until Antonio can start sending money again.

donationDescription:
I want to thank you for your generosity and I also want to share with you my story. I’ve been here in Vermont for 5 years. My husband has been working at the same farm for 10 years. I am taking care of the calves at the farm. My shifts start every morning at 3:00 am, even in winter. I like cows a lot and taking care of the calves is something that I enjoy. But poor creatures, they get separated from their mom when they are young and they cry for their mother. There are many times in which they become so depressed that they refuse to eat, and I have to remove my gloves in the cold in order to coax them into drinking the milk. I like cows a lot and when they separate the calves they are so rough and kick around so much that you end up crying. They don’t know what’s going on and it’s not their fault.
The harder aspect of my job is having to clean the troughs the cows eat from. We use acids to clean them and sometimes I accidentally forget to put on my gloves. I end up hurting my hands, but I keep working. Whenever the boss sees me, he tells me he loves me in English and in the past he would also give me a hug. It’s because he sees me singing to the calves often; they like hearing me sing.
 I work nearly 78 hours per week. Tuesday is my day off, but I cook and sell food for the farm community and I also clean houses because I am still paying off the debt from childbirth, a lot of money is discounted from my check.
My child was born 2 years ago here in Vermont and I had to stop working to take care of him, but I needed the money to send it to my mother because my husband and I were building her a house, so we decided to send our kid to Mexico with my mother so I could continue working. This decision was the hardest ever, but my mother is very happy taking care of him. My husband and I are now building a house for us and for our 2 year old in Veracruz. We are also saving money for his education.
My husband and I are asking for a pair of sneakers and hiking sandals because in the summer our feet get tired and really hot in boots. I like Vermont a lot. The people are really nice. I like the lakes and the people are great with us. They love me a lot at our farm. Everyone respects me. I also want to thank you for your generous donations, they mean a lot to us because with our shifts we hardly have time to do any shopping. And there are police patrols all over the roads, so we just go from our house to the farm and back. Thank you. May God spread all his blessings to you and your families.

You also can make a partial payment towards this bill by making a general donation and noting in the comments that it should be applied to Carlo's medical bill.

Carlos, who is 45 years old, works 10-12 hours a day 6 days a week at a farm in Addison County, VT.  On Saturday 6/6/2020 he injured his foot. The ex-ray showed a fracture  that required surgery.  He continued to work even after the fracture but had surgery on Wednesday 6/10/20 at Porter Hospital in Middlebury, VT. Carlos, a Mexican citizen, is in America to earn money to better support his family in Mexico which consists of his aging parents, wife and son who has muscular dystrophy.  Carlos pays for his son's bi-weekly medical visits with a specialist.  Carlos does not qualify for any medical insurance plan and does not receive medical insurance through his work.  He cannot claim relatives in Mexico as dependents for purposes of financial assistance through the hospital.  He has incurred medical bills amounting to tens of thousands of dollars.  Making payments on this bill will severely inhibit his ability to continue to provide for his family.  Carlos would appreciate any support to help him pay this bill. The total bill left to pay is still over $10,000.00.

This decision was the hardest ever, but my mother is very happy taking care of him. My husband and I are now building a house for us and for our 2 year old in Veracruz. We are also saving money for his education.
My husband and I are asking for a pair of sneakers and hiking sandals because in the summer our feet get tired and really hot in boots. I like Vermont a lot. The people are really nice. I like the lakes and the people are great with us. They love me a lot at our farm. Everyone respects me. I also want to thank you for your generous donations, they mean a lot to us because with our shifts we hardly have time to do any shopping. And there are police patrols all over the roads, so we just go from our house to the farm and back. Thank you. May God spread all his blessings to you and your families.

donationDescription:
I want to thank you for your generosity and I also want to share with you my story. I’ve been here in Vermont for 5 years. My husband has been working at the same farm for 10 years. I am taking care of the calves at the farm. My shifts start every morning at 3:00 am, even in winter. I like cows a lot and taking care of the calves is something that I enjoy. But poor creatures, they get separated from their mom when they are young and they cry for their mother. There are many times in which they become so depressed that they refuse to eat, and I have to remove my gloves in the cold in order to coax them into drinking the milk. I like cows a lot and when they separate the calves they are so rough and kick around so much that you end up crying. They don’t know what’s going on and it’s not their fault.
The harder aspect of my job is having to clean the troughs the cows eat from. We use acids to clean them and sometimes I accidentally forget to put on my gloves. I end up hurting my hands, but I keep working. Whenever the boss sees me, he tells me he loves me in English and in the past he would also give me a hug. It’s because he sees me singing to the calves often; they like hearing me sing.
 I work nearly 78 hours per week. Tuesday is my day off, but I cook and sell food for the farm community and I also clean houses because I am still paying off the debt from childbirth, a lot of money is discounted from my check.
My child was born 2 years ago here in Vermont and I had to stop working to take care of him, but I needed the money to send it to my mother because my husband and I were building her a house, so we decided to send our kid to Mexico with my mother so I could continue working. This decision was the hardest ever, but my mother is very happy taking care of him. My husband and I are now building a house for us and for our 2 year old in Veracruz. We are also saving money for his education.
My husband and I are asking for a pair of sneakers and hiking sandals because in the summer our feet get tired and really hot in boots. I like Vermont a lot. The people are really nice. I like the lakes and the people are great with us. They love me a lot at our farm. Everyone respects me. I also want to thank you for your generous donations, they mean a lot to us because with our shifts we hardly have time to do any shopping. And there are police patrols all over the roads, so we just go from our house to the farm and back. Thank you. May God spread all his blessings to you and your families.

donationDescription:
My nickname here at the dairy farm community is “El niño”, kid, because I arrived here to Vermont after my 17th birthday. I have only been in Vermont for three months and though I have felt nostalgic being away from home, the farm community has been very welcoming.  I come from a remote community in the highlands of Chiapas State of Southern Mexico, in the border with Guatemala. At home, I lived with my mother and my 2 younger brothers. We are very much uncommunicated because they live by the mountains and there’s no internet reception in my town. So far the weather hasn’t treated me badly yet I have heard that Vermont winters are very long and cold. The farmworkers here have been so nice to me, they have supported me in many ways. I have learnt a lot about the dairy farm and the cows. I like it a lot and all the money I make, I’m sending it to my mother to support her with my brothers. I work 75 hrs a week and the community here has become my family. Being only seventeen I have had to adapt and mature at an early age but I know that this is an investment I am making for the betterment of myself and my family. 
Cooking for me is a way of decompressing, and also a therapy to distract myself from our hard labor at the farm. One of my house mates is teaching me how to make cheese. I would also appreciate it if you can contribute with Rennet tablets so I can make my own cheese to share with my housemates. I would also very much appreciate it if you can support me with a manual corn mill to grind corn in order to make tortillas.  I miss my mother’s handmade tortillas and I would love to make them for the dairy farm community. Finally I would also appreciate receiving an AC unit so that I can have for the rest of the summer and the summers that await me.

donationDescription: I have been working at this dairy farm for 12 years. Sometimes I have worked up to 80 hours in one week. donationDescription:
As new arrivals to the United States, this client and her family are currently learning English. A television would allow the client to learn English and stay up-to-date on what is going on in Charlotte, which is a matter of safety and community integration. This is even more pressing since ESL classes can not currently take place in person, due to Coronavirus. Additionally, this client is elderly and can not work, so a television would give her something to do and allow her to connect to her new home.
In order for the clients to watch television and gain all of the benefits associated with this, they will need a television antenna. As they are not yet able to afford cable, the antenna is necessary for the television to work.

I send them all my money, and we have a dream to build a little house. I work 75 hrs a week, and every time someone gets sick I cover for them because I’m blessed to have a job and to be able to support my family. I also send money to my mother. If you can help me with a pair of Men’s Sneakers, I would be very thankful.

donationDescription:
Frank's B-Day fundraiser donated $150.00 towards these boots!
Hello, my name is Alberto and I have been living here in the Upper Valley for 7 years. I have worked at a dairy farm for more than 5 years, and before I was working in the NorthEast Kingdom at another farm. I am very content at the farm that I am at because we receive good treatment. I work an average of 72 hours a week. I am from Martinez de la Torre, a small town in Veracruz Mexico. When I left my hometown more than 7 years ago it took me more than a month to get here to NH. My cousin was already here working so he convinced me to give it a try because the situation in my hometown was difficult. Not only the social aspect was getting scary and violent, but also it was very hard to find a job. I am single. I help my parents and some other relatives. I provide for them. I miss my mother a lot, but it makes me happy that with the money that I’m sending for them she is making improvements in her house and she is taking care of my dad’s health. Thank you so much for your help. I am so grateful that I have a job to support my family. I need a pair of  Men’s Workman Waterproof Insulated Boots, these would help me a lot because I take long shifts at the milk station and it's often muddy and slippery. Thank you very much and God bless you.

donationDescription: I moved from Chiapas, Mexico to the US 6 years ago, chasing the American Dream. I left behind my wife and 3 children. It has been very hard for me to be away from my dear ones. I have been working for a dairy farm since my arrival. I work over 70 hrs a week and I’m always available to take someone else’s shift if they cannot work for any reason. I love helping my peers. All my earnings are committed to my family, including my parents. My wife and my children live with them. Just recently I finished building the kitchen in my house in Mexico. My 3 children are attending school and I’m paying for all that. I also support my mother and my father. I know that I’m here to work and I don’t complain. I am thankful that my family in Chiapas is doing better. They eat well and they have a roof. With the covid-19 breakout the situation has become scary around here. It’s difficult to find stores that are open and with my working schedule, no car and no license it has become hard to buy some essential needs. I would highly appreciate a pair of boots. I need them for my work. Thank you once again for your kindness and God bless you.

donationDescription: Hello, My name is Andrew and I come from Martinez de la Torre in Veracruz, Mexico. I have only been in the Upper Valley for about two years but the treatment I have received from the people of Vermont and New Hampshire has been superior to what I received in my previous location in Michigan. I am a father of three children, two sons and one daughter, but they are all back home in Mexico with my wife. Moving to the United States has been one of the biggest sacrifices I have made in my lifetime, especially leaving my whole family behind and missing out from some of the prime years of my children. Back in Mexico I worked as a handyman but the level of pay was not enough to sustain my family or provide them with the stability that they deserve. Currently I work an average of 70+ hours  at the farm and most of that money I am sending home to pay for my children's education, and for their food and housing. Even though it is hard being without my family, I thank the world everyday for keeping me healthy to continue to take part in this labor that I have grown a great affection towards. I would be eternally thankful if you could help me through your generous funds to have access to one or more of the items I am requesting above. Your gifts are not only a donation, but they make a tremendous difference in giving us the tools and comfort we need to continue to take part in our jobs to the best of our ability. Thank you for your graceful work.

donationDescription:
Thank you to a donor who contributed $100.00 to these boots!
Hello, my name is Rose and I have only been in the Upper Valley for slightly over one year. The economical situation in the region of Mexico from where I am from was in very bad conditions so my sister convinced me to come to this region in search of better financial opportunity. Being only 20 years old, I decided to make this difficult decision to move to a new country, and a different culture because I know that with hard work I will hopefully be able to reach a sufficiently stable financial situation to go back to Mexico and pursue a college education. I hope to at some point in my life get a degree in Business and Administration and my dream is to open some sort of sustainable business back in my hometown that will be a strong source of employment and create good financial stability. Currently I am working at a dairy farm and I work an average of 60 hour weeks, of which I mainly spend milking cows. Currently my sister handed me down her old pair of boots and would greatly appreciate a new pair of work boots that will hopefully last me for several years. I am also requesting a pair of comfortable Nike sneakers because I spend a lot of time helping my sister with her newborn son and helping her with her cooking business. Thank you so much for all that you do for our community!

donationDescription:
Romi is a refugee from Indonesia who came to the United States to flee religious persecution. He lives in Lebanon with his wife and two children. As a conceptual artist and graphic designer, he needs a creative graphics tablet to build his portfolio and find work remotely. He has just obtained his work permit and works 18 hours a week in a low-skilled job that does not provide enough for the family because he does not have this essential equipment to find a job suited to his skills. Thank you in advance for your help in this project. 
He would be forever grateful to anyone who can help him in his quest for dignity and sustainability. Currently, the family is living in a one-bedroom apartment, which is mostly funded by generous people.

donationDescription: Hello, my name is Ernesto and I have been working on a farm in North Haverhill, Vermont for the last eight years. I am single and I decided to move to the United States to help my parents live a life of greater dignity and stability. It has been so hard to be so far away from my parents, especially because I haven’t been able to see them physically for the last eight years. I work an average of 10-12 hour shifts six days a week and just a few years ago I decided to take the night shifts which go from 1am-1pm because the pay is slightly improved. At times, it has been tough for me to stay motivated, and passionate but the farm community has been so welcoming and supportive to me. One of my highlights every week is getting together with farm workers from different farms to play soccer on Fridays and Sundays. Even though both those days I work at 1am, soccer helps me so much in liberating any stress I might have. I am hoping that one of you would be so kind in donating a pair of work boots for my labor.

donationDescription: Hello, my name is Rose and I have only been in the Upper Valley for slightly over one year. The economical situation in the region of Mexico from where I am from was in very bad conditions so my sister convinced me to come to this region in search of better financial opportunity. Being only 20 years old, I decided to make this difficult decision to move to a new country, and a different culture because I know that with hard work I will hopefully be able to reach a sufficiently stable financial situation to go back to Mexico and pursue a college education. I hope to at some point in my life get a degree in Business and Administration and my dream is to open some sort of sustainable business back in my hometown that will be a strong source of employment and create good financial stability. Currently I am working at a dairy farm and I work an average of 60 hour weeks, of which I mainly spend milking cows. Currently my sister handed me down her old pair of boots and would greatly appreciate a new pair of work boots that will hopefully last me for several years. I am also requesting a pair of comfortable Nike sneakers because I spend a lot of time helping my sister with her newborn son and helping her with her cooking business. Thank you so much for all that you do for our community!

donationDescription:
Romi is a refugee from Indonesia who came to the United States to flee religious persecution. He lives in Lebanon with his wife and two children. As a conceptual artist and graphic designer, he needs a creative graphics tablet to build his portfolio and find work remotely. He has just obtained his work permit and works 18 hours a week in a low-skilled job that does not provide enough for the family because he does not have this essential equipment to find a job suited to his skills. Thank you in advance for your help in this project. 
He would be forever grateful to anyone who can help him in his quest for dignity and sustainability. Currently, the family is living in a one-bedroom apartment, which is mostly funded by generous people.

donationDescription: Jaba is an asylee from Bangladesh currently living in Queens, NY. At the age of 30, Jaba has recently graduated from college. This is a great accomplishment and has prepared Jaba to start a career in the United States now that she has been granted asylum. Having a laptop computer will help her to apply for jobs online on her own and to work from home once she has secured a job. The COVID-19 pandemic has pushed many jobs to virtual platforms, and without a computer with access to the internet, Jaba will be unable to work. It is important to Jaba to be a productive and self-sufficient member of American society, and acquiring a laptop computer from which she can search for and secure full-time employment in her field is the first step to that goal.

donationDescription:
My name is Freddy. I am 24 years old. I arrived to Vermont 9 months ago and I have never seen snow before. In my hometown the weather is not so extreme. My dream is to save money to build a house for my parents and to buy a piece of land so when I return I can marry and have children. I have been working at the same farm since my arrival. I sometimes work up to 78 hrs a week. I have been very homesick but I’m thankful for the opportunity to be able to have a job now more than ever. It is very hard in my community in Mexico with Coronavirus. I send most of my money to my parents to support my siblings. I need a pair of boots to survive the winter. I have seen that my peers wear this kind of boots because they have a good grip. I work at the milk stations with the robots.
Thank you very much for your support. God bless you all!

donationDescription:
When refugees come to the U.S., they bring with them important documents from overseas, and upon arrival, they are inundated with more papers and mail from public benefits offices, doctors, school along with regular junk mail. For those without English – the majority—keeping track of key documents and providing them when needed is challenging. Papers are lost or misplaced. Staff time is lost too. A solution emerged when one of our recent Burmese arrivals came with their own binder with plastic inserts containing their important documents. Staff recognized how this simple tool is the solution to this nagging problem, a problem that could result in the delay of critical supports. With this request, we look forward to helping our next 10 refugee families stay organized and more involved in their resettlement process.
 
Jewish Family and Community Services runs many programs for refugees and vulnerable immigrants living in Pittsburgh. Our professional team, assisted by interns, AmeriCorps and volunteers, help families transition to their new American home.

donationDescription: Good afternoon. I arrived in the Upper Valley a year ago. My name is Luisito but my nick name here at the dairy farm community is “niño”, kid, because I’m the youngest one. I was 17 when I arrived.  I turned 18 here. I come from a remote community in the highlands of Chiapas State of Southern Mexico, in the border with Guatemala. At home, I live with my mother and my 2 younger brothers. We are very much uncommunicated because we live by the mountains and there’s no internet reception in my town. It was hard for me to adapt to Vermont’s weather and being away from my family is very difficult for me. My mother is a single mother. We have a tiny home made of steel sheets and I promised my mother that I was going to build her a home, made of cement. I work a lot, sometimes more than 74 hrs a week. I’m thankful for all the things that I have learned here at the dairy farm. I love my job and I love to be able to support my mother and my siblings. I send them all my money. I would appreciate it if  Hearts you Hold can support me with a pair of boots, and a winter jacket. I have never felt so cold in my life and it is very hard to work when you are not feeling warm. The winter here is painful. Thank you very much for your support.

donationDescription: This mother is one of our Healthy Start very proactive clients. She moved to the U.S. 6 years ago, has a 13-year-old son who is autistic and a 3-month-old baby who was born very healthy. During the COVID pandemic this mother was laid off but was not eligible for unemployment as she is an immigrant making it impossible to pay rent. She has been able to keep up with some of the bills. The father of the baby has walked away from his responsibilities but she continues to do her best at following up with all the resources that have been given to her by her care coordinator. Thankfully, she is back to work 3 times a week and she hopes to be back full time very soon. Amazingly, she continues to see the bright side of things and continues to learn new skills as a parent. Note: this rent is for a 2-bedroom apartment in low to middle income housing. Your one-time donation will help her catch up and continue making up her own rent going forward.

donationDescription: My name is Zeke, I have been here in VT for two years but I was living close to Burlington at a dairy farm. Unfortunately, after two years of hard work I decided to move because the working conditions were poor, and I don’t have a car and it was very hard to get food. I’m happier here in this new farm because the community is very kind and respectful. I am from Veracruz, I’m 30 years old and I have two kids. I work an estimate of 74 hours a week. I don’t complain about it because this is what I’m here for. To provide for my family. I would like to build a little house for my wife and my two kids. I was hoping that Hearts you Hold could support me with a pair of boots for winter. We wear them out fast here at the dairy farm with our intense long shifts. Thank you very much. God bless you.

donationDescription: Hello Hearts You Hold,  my name is Joselyn. I have been working at the same dairy farm for 8 years here in New Hampshire. I am working at the bottling and creamery area. I arrived here at the age of 19. I left my son behind in Guerrero, Mexico. I became a mother at the age of 15 and I could not find a job to provide for him. I work an average of 72 hours a week. My day off is Saturday. I’m sending money to my grandmother and my great grandmother in Guerrero. They raised me and they are taking care of my child who is now 10 years old. I don’t have a car and I don’t drive, therefore it’s difficult for me to get the things I need. I would very much appreciate it if you can support me with a parka for winter. I’m thankful for your support. Winter is tough at the milking station. The parka would help me a lot through my night shifts. Thank you very much.

donationDescription: Hi, my name is Brad, and I am 36 years old. I work at a dairy farm in NH. I have been here for almost 3 years. I live with my cousin and his girlfriend. I moved here because it was hard to find a job in my hometown. I work 74 hrs a week, helping at the milk stations and cleaning the barns. I come from Alvarado, Veracruz and I have 3 kids. I send all my money to my wife to support her with our kids and I also send money to my parents because we are very poor, they are getting old and they need my help. I want to thank you all for being so kind and helping us with winter clothes for work. I don’t have a car and I don’t go out anywhere. The milking barn is pretty much an extension of my home here in the Upper Valley. I’m thankful for the opportunity to have a job. I am asking for support with a cargo winter coat. Thank you always for your generosity.

donationDescription: Hi, my name is Brad, and I am 36 years old. I work at a dairy farm in NH. I have been here for almost 3 years. I live with my cousin and his girlfriend. I moved here because it was hard to find a job in my hometown. I work 74 hrs a week, helping at the milk stations and cleaning the barns. I come from Alvarado, Veracruz and I have 3 kids. I send all my money to my wife to support her with our kids and I also send money to my parents because we are very poor, they are getting old and they need my help. I want to thank you all for being so kind and helping us with winter clothes for work. I don’t have a car and I don’t go out anywhere. The milking barn is pretty much an extension of my home here in the Upper Valley. I’m thankful for the opportunity to have a job. I need a good pair of boots with good insulation and good grip to be able to work safely. Thank you always for your generosity.

donationDescription: Roubine came to the United States from Togo as an unaccompanied minor last year. The journey was difficult and dangerous. After arriving in the U.S., Roubine was eventually placed with his aunt, Sabi, who is currently sponsoring him. Sabi is a single mother of 4 and a recent migrant herself, but she has accepted Roubine into her home lovingly. The family is struggling to make ends meet with five mouths to feed and only one breadwinner. Right now, their greatest need is winter clothing and coats for the children. Roubine, Sabi, and the whole family would be very grateful for any help offered.

donationDescription: Alhassane is an asylee from Guinea who arrived in New York this September to be reunited with his wife and children, who have been living in the U.S. as asylees for some time. He is overjoyed to be back with his family in a safe place, but he is struggling with the adjustment to his new situation. Alhassane is currently trying to learn English online, since most ESOL classes in the city are taught remotely online due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.  Alhassane and his family have no computer and only one cell phone, which they must all share. In order to attend his English classes more efficiently and learn the language, Alhassane needs a laptop computer. The donation of technology will allow Alhassane to attend his classes, apply for jobs online, connect virtually with his family at home in Guinea, and much more. This donation will help Alhassane and his family a great deal and is much appreciated.

donationDescription: Leonardo is from Cuba and was released from detention this fall. He and his cousin, Maikel, recently saved up enough to move from the shelter they were staying at to a small apartment in Brooklyn and are adjusting to their new lives in New York City. They have work authorization, but are both finding it difficult to find a stable job without proficient English language skills.  They do not have the financial support of friends or family. In order to learn English, the two cousins are taking English classes online (since in-person instruction is unavailable due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic). In order to attend his classes online, Leonardo needs a device to access the internet. Donating a device to Leonardo will allow him to attend English classes and start his journey of integration into American society. Learning English is an important factor in restarting his life as self-sufficient member of society, and your assistance will be very much appreciated.

donationDescription:
Mindi came to the United States with her mom and brother in the summer of 2018 from Mexico to request asylum, during the time in which children and parents were being separated at the border.  She and her family were reunited, and she began high school in the United States.  Within a year of arrival, she graduated high school while her family pursued their legal cases. She is a bright, very motivated learner who is overcoming many barriers.  Her family has been slowly trying to save money so that Mindi can attend college, and she will be starting a community college in January 2021.  Mindi needs a laptop to use to complete her classes so that she can follow her dreams to graduate college and be the first in her family to do so.   

Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.
**Thank you donor #1 for reducing the cost by $50.00!"

donationDescription: My name is Aaron. I come from Chiapas, Mexico and I arrived in Vermont 3 months ago. I’m dreading winter. It’s very hot and humid in my hometown. I’m 20 years old. It took me over a month to get here to Vermont and I still owe money ($12,000.00) from the trip. I work at a dairy farm 80 hrs a week. I have learned a lot. This is all new to me, but I have energy and good health to work. My family and I are very poor. My mother is a single mom with 5 kids. I’m the oldest one. Since the pandemic began, things got very hard for her. She was a domestic employee, but she lost her job. That’s mainly the reason why I decided to come to the US. I wanted to be the head of the household. I’m proud to be sending her all my money, to support the family. I would like to save money to build her a little house. We have a tiny house with two bedrooms and a tin roof. I want my siblings to continue studying. That’s why I’m here. I don’t know where to buy things around here and I’m in need of a winter jacket and a pair of boots size 9. My peers have mentioned to me that Hearts you Hold supports us with our basic needs like winter gear, etc. Thank you so much.

donationDescription: Hello Hearts you hold and thank you for showing your appreciation to us. We feel invisible sometimes around here. It is very hard to be away from the family during Christmas. My name is Marty and I moved to the Upper Valley 10 years ago chasing the American Dream. I left behind my parents and siblings. I am married and have a boy. I work over 74 hrs a week at a dairy farm, milking the cows and driving the trucks for whatever is needed. I send money to my parents to support them. My dad lost his job after the pandemic. I’m here to work and I am fortunate to have a job. I like what I do and my boss at the farm is a noble man, kind hearted.  I wear boots with good grip and insulation to work, but sometimes my feet need a rest. So I’m asking for a pair of light weight boots.  Thank you once again for your kindness and God bless you all and Merry Christmas!

donationDescription: Since the COVID pandemic started, things got really tough in my hometown in Mexico. I lost my job, my wife was pregnant and I decided to come here to work to provide for my parents and my wife. I arrived in the Upper Valley 2 month ago. I’ve been told that winter is hard. I have never seen the snow in my life. I work at a dairy farm 74 hrs a week.  I have different shifts milking cows at the barns and supervising the robots and the milk production in an area with over 200 cows. I’m 20 years old and I’m a hardworking man. I’m in need of some winter gear to get me through this season. I would be grateful if Hearts You Hold could support me with a couple of things, I need a jacket, a pair of mittens and a hat. Thank You Hearts You Hold and Happy Christmas!

donationDescription:
The Newcomer program is geared for our newest refugee youth from grades K-12. A program director oversees this once-week mentor-based virtual program meant to build English language and social skills through fun, engaging activities.
We'd like to create individual "Activity Boxes" for each of the 25 youth. HYH already helped with journals and small whiteboards.
Mentees will be able to use construction paper to create craft projects with their mentors during their virtual mentoring sessions or on their own time. Construction paper will allow the youth participants to get creative. This paper will be used in tandem with the glue, scissors, markers, and stickers we also intend to provide. 
Jewish Family and Community Services runs many programs for refugees and vulnerable immigrants living in Pittsburgh. Our professional team, assisted by interns, AmeriCorps and volunteers, help families transition to their new American home.

donationDescription: Khadim is an asylee from Senegal currently living in New York with a friend who is supporting him as he adjusts to life in the U.S. This fall, Khadim was granted asylum status and moved to New York to start his new life. He is currently in the process of integrating into life in the U.S. and preparing to start a career in the United States. Khadim is grateful for the help of his friend, but does not want to burden others and wishes to become self-sufficient soon. As he prepares to enter the work force, Khadim is trying to improve his English language skills. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, English classes are being held online, and Khadim is in need of a computer to access the internet and attend his classes. Having a laptop computer will also help him apply for jobs online and to work from home safely once he has secured a job. The COVID-19 pandemic has pushed many jobs to virtual platforms, and without a computer with access to the internet, Khadim may be unable to work. It is important to Khadim to support himself financially and repay his friends who have helped him, and acquiring a laptop computer from which he can learn English and secure full-time employment is the first step to that goal.

She recently was able to get a part time job in retail as COVID-19 restrictions have eased, but it is not enough to support her family of 3. Her daughters, Amery and Shalia, are in need of new clothing as they are growing quickly. Belkis needs assistance paying for the girls’ clothes, as she has no extra money to spend after months of budgeting. Any assistance would be appreciated by Belkis and her daughters.

donationDescription: Arline is an asylee from Venezuela. She has lived in New York for about a year and recently gave birth to a daughter. Arline is living in Queens with her fiancé and young daughter. Since her baby is only a few months old, Arline is nervous about putting her in childcare so young, especially in the COIVD-19 pandemic, and is unable to work while she cares for her daughter full time. Arline’s fiancé is working, but his income is barely enough to support the young family. Arline was a human rights lawyer for children and adolescents for over 10 years in Venezuela, and hopes to one day practice law in the U.S. When her daughter is a bit older, Arline would like to start working again and start the process of passing the New York bar exam. While Arline is not working, the family is struggling to afford basic necessities like diapers for their daughter. This donation of diapers would allow Arline and her fiancé to keep their daughter safe, clean, and healthy this month. Your help will alleviate financial stress for the family and allow them to focus on the wellbeing of their child.

donationDescription:
***Thank you to five generous donors whose donations total $2200.00 towards this bill.
You also can make a partial payment towards this bill by making a general donation and noting in the comments that it should be applied to Carlo's medical bill.

Carlos, who is 45 years old, works 10-12 hours a day 6 days a week at a farm in Addison County, VT.  On Saturday 6/6/2020 he injured his foot. The ex-ray showed a fracture  that required surgery.  He continued to work even after the fracture but had surgery on Wednesday 6/10/20 at Porter Hospital in Middlebury, VT. Carlos, a Mexican citizen, is in America to earn money to better support his family in Mexico which consists of his aging parents, wife and son who has muscular dystrophy.  Carlos pays for his son's bi-weekly medical visits with a specialist.  Carlos does not qualify for any medical insurance plan and does not receive medical insurance through his work.  He cannot claim relatives in Mexico as dependents for purposes of financial assistance through the hospital.  He has incurred medical bills amounting to tens of thousands of dollars.  Making payments on this bill will severely inhibit his ability to continue to provide for his family.  Carlos would appreciate any support to help him pay this bill. The total bill left to pay is still over $10,000.00. The original bill was $31,200.00.

donationDescription: Simon traveled to New York from Venezuela with his wife and daughter last summer, and was granted asylum in the fall. Simon and his wife fled the humanitarian crisis and widespread violence in Venezuela in order to provide a safe and stable home for their young daughter, Mia. Mia is two years old and growing every day. Simon’s wife is staying home to take care of Mia, and Simon is currently looking for work. Simon hopes to be able to support himself and his family and become self-sufficient, but for now he needs help caring for his family. Diapers are a big expense that are not included in government assistance programs and hard to find at food banks and other charities. Simon needs help getting diapers for his daughter to keep her clean and healthy. Any help will be appreciated by the Bolivar family.

donationDescription: Georgette is an asylee from Burkina Faso who moved to New York with her family in 2018. She has four children and is expecting her 5th child next week. Georgette works as home health aide, but has been unemployed since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, so her husband's income has been stretched to support the whole family. She has been helping her children with online schooling from home and preparing for the arrival of her new baby girl. The family has been working with Catholic Charities since they were granted asylum in 2019 and have made tremendous progress, but still need help from time to time. One of the family’s most pressing needs right now is diapers for their new baby. A donation of diapers will allow Georgette to keep her newborn daughter safe, clean, and healthy for an entire month. Georgette is very grateful for any help you can offer.

donationDescription: Elsa is an asylee from El Salvador who is living and working in Bronx, NY. Elsa traveled to the U.S. in 2019 and was granted asylum. She is the mother of two children, a 6 year old son who traveled with her from El Salvador and a new baby girl who was born here in New York. Elsa hopes that she can make a better life for her children in New York and is working hard to build that life despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.  Elsa was recently able to save up enough to get an apartment for herself and her children in the Bronx. Living alone with her children thousands of miles away from any friends or family has been difficult, but Elsa is happy to have their new apartment.  Elsa and the children still have a lot of needs as a newly arrived asylees, and their apartment is mostly empty. Elsa does not have the money to fully furnish and decorate her new apartment. Catholic Charities is helping Elsa get donated furniture for the apartment, but there are still many items she needs to buy herself. Right now, the item Elsa needs most is blinds or curtains for the windows in her apartment. The apartment Elsa rents has two windows, and without blinds anyone outside could see in at night. Elsa lives on the first floor and worries for the safety of her children in the apartment if others can see in. She would really appreciate any help getting blinds for their windows so she and her children can have privacy and feel safer in their apartment. Any help or donation would be appreciated.

donationDescription: Sobia J. is an asylee from Pakistan who gained asylum status in 2019. She was a journalist in Pakistan and has extensive experience in human rights advocacy and research. This brave work put Sobia in danger, however, and she was targeted for her political views and forced to flee to the U.S. Sobia has two young children, a 7-year-old daughter and a son who just turned 2. She is not working right now, but has been looking for a job for some time. The Covid-19 pandemic has affected her ability to work since there are fewer jobs available and safe childcare is increasingly difficult to find. Sobia hopes to eventually return to a career in journalism and continue researching and exposing human rights abuses. Sobia is working towards self-sufficiency and hopes to be able to provide for her children fully and give them a safe and comfortable life, but she still needs some help. Without any disposable income, Sobia cannot buy the computer she needs that would allow her to work from home while safely caring for her children. This donation would go a long way in helping Sobia achieve self-sufficiency.

donationDescription: Yisel is a Cuban parole who arrived in New York last fall. Yisel is currently living with family in upper Manhattan and receiving services from Catholic Charities Community Services Refugee Resettlement program. Yisel is working toward getting her Employment Authorization Document (EAD) so she can work in the U.S. and earn money to support herself and her family. Yisel’s family is helping her with the large expense of applying for an EAD. Yisel wants to work and was a professional volleyball player in Cuba. She is interested in pursuing education or nursing. While she is in the process of getting work authorization, Yisel is working on improving her English language skills through a full-time intensive ESOL class. In order to participate in this class, which is being held online due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, Yisel needs a computer. Yisel currently has no form of income and her family, who are already housing her and helping her pay for her work authorization, cannot afford to buy her a laptop. This donation will allow Yisel to safely learn English and participate fully in her classes. It will also help Yisel with job searching and potentially working or attending higher education remotely once she is settled and has her EAD approved.

donationDescription: Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.  Delfina is a single mother to three young children, including her 9 year old brother who was recently orphaned in Guatemala.  Due to the cost of childcare, she cannot afford to work outside the home.  She works selling food she prepares at home on construction sites, bringing her children with her.  She is requesting a full-size microwave and a large capacity blender to help prepare food to sell as well as to prepare for her children.  These items will help her make money to support herself and her children, as this is her only source of income.

donationDescription: Aleksandra is an asylee from Russia who fled to the U.S. in 2019 with her three children. Aleksandra and her children lived in a shelter until recently when she was able to save up enough to move into a small apartment of their own. Aleksandra is working hard to provide for her children, but cannot work many hours because she needs to take care of them, so her income is sometimes not enough to cover basic needs for the family. One necessity that is especially expensive and that Aleksandra often cannot afford is diapers for her son. Aleksandra’s youngest son has developmental issues and needs to wear diapers at all times for his health and hygiene. Assistance programs like SNAP and WIC do not cover diaper costs, and Aleksandra often finds that she cannot afford to buy the diaper training pants for her son.  Any donation toward diapers for her son would be extremely helpful, and Aleksandra is grateful for any help.

donationDescription:
The family that we are requesting this laptop for arrived in the United States just a couple years ago. Mom and grandma would love to register for online English classes so they can continue learning during the pandemic and they need a laptop to participate effectively.
This laptop would help a wonderful family on their way to a brighter future! Thank you!

Catholic Charities Atlanta serves refugee and immigrant families during their first few years in the United States. Many of the families we serve come from Southeast Asia, the Middle East, Central-East Africa, and Central America.

donationDescription: Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.  Delfina is a single mother to three young children, including her 9 year old brother who was recently orphaned in Guatemala.  Due to the cost of childcare, she cannot afford to work outside the home.  She works selling food she prepares at home on construction sites, bringing her children with her.  She is requesting a full-size microwave and a large capacity blender to help prepare food to sell as well as to prepare for her children.  These items will help her make money to support herself and her children, as this is her only source of income.

donationDescription: Colombe and Maria are sisters from Brazzaville in Congo who fled violence in 2017 when they were both teenagers. Colombe, who is now 23, is blind and lives with the double burden of being a disabled refugee. The girls had to separate from their parents and move out alone in 2019 and have lived in various shelters until last month, when they were able to move into an apartment. Moving into a home of their own for the first time, the girls have many new expenses that they are struggling to pay on Colombe’s income. Colombe works as a gas station attendant and Maria is still looking for a job. Colombe and Maria need clothing, shoes, furniture, and other small home items.  Any help would be really appreciated by Maria and Colombe as they start to rebuild their lives in their new home in the Bronx.
recipientUSLocation: Bronx, NY - Democratic Republic of the Congo

donationDescription: Amadou is a 63 year old asylee from Guinea who fled violence and torture in his home region in 2019, following his wife Housseynatou who was granted asylum in the U.S. a few months before Amadou. Amadou slowly adjusted to his new home in New York and got a job working for Amazon to deliver packages in Brooklyn. In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, Amadou lost his job at Amazon due to company layoffs and has been struggling financially since. Amadou enrolled in an Catholic Charities employment assistance program, and he recently got a job working for Fedex. Amadou is grateful to be able to work again and get back on his feet after a difficult few months. Amadou’s new job is a long commute from his apartment, however, and is difficult to get to at the late night hour of his night shift. Amadou is looking for a bicycle he could use to get to work for his night shift, when there are fewer buses and subways available. This is an expensive item for Amadou to purchase alone after months of unemployment, and any help would be greatly appreciated.

donationDescription: Colombe and Maria are sisters from Brazzaville in Congo who fled violence in 2017 when they were both teenagers. Colombe, who is now 23, is blind and lives with the double burden of being a disabled refugee. The girls had to separate from their parents and move out alone in 2019 and have lived in various shelters until last month, when they were able to move into an apartment. Moving into a home of their own for the first time, the girls have many new expenses that they are struggling to pay on Colombe’s income. Colombe works as a gas station attendant and Maria is still looking for a job. Colombe and Maria need clothing, shoes, furniture, and other small home items.  Any help would be really appreciated by Maria and Colombe as they start to rebuild their lives in their new home in the Bronx.

Katherin and her son were then placed in the care of her older brother as her sponsor, who was already living in the U.S. with his wife and their six children. Katherin moved into their apartment in Roosevelt a few weeks ago. Katherine and her baby are in need of essentials, as they currently have nothing and Katherin has no form of income. Katherin hopes to enroll in high school in the fall and is focused on adjusting to her new life as a mom and a New Yorker.

donationDescription: Colombe and Maria are sisters from Brazzaville in Congo who fled violence in 2017 when they were both teenagers. Colombe, who is now 23, is blind and lives with the double burden of being a disabled refugee. The girls had to separate from their parents and move out alone in 2019 and have lived in various shelters until last month, when they were able to move into an apartment. Moving into a home of their own for the first time, the girls have many new expenses that they are struggling to pay on Colombe’s income. Colombe works as a gas station attendant and Maria is still looking for a job. Colombe and Maria need clothing, shoes, furniture, and other small home items.  Any help would be really appreciated by Maria and Colombe as they start to rebuild their lives in their new home in the Bronx.
recipientUSLocation: Bronx, NY - Democratic Republic of the Congo

donationDescription:
Victor is a 16 year old from Guatemala who is newly arrived to the United States.  He has reunited with his father after 15 years of separation, and is adjusting to his new community and placement.  Victor has requested a bicycle and helmet so that he can get exercise.  He lives in a large mobile home park with lots of small paved streets which allow for him to ride his bike safely close to home.  This bicycle will help provide a healthy outlet for coping with the many changes he's experienced and give him a small measure of independence.   

Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription:
Victor is a 16 year old Guatemalan male who is newly arrived to the United States.  He has reunited with his father after 15 years of separation, and is adjusting to his new community and placement.  His father plays the guitar, and would like to teach Victor to play as a bonding activity to build their relationship.  Victor is eager to spend time with his dad and learn to play the guitar.   They request an electric guitar.
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Ayse is an asylee from Burkina Faso who is living with friends in Brooklyn, New York. She was granted asylum status in the U.S. in April 2021 and has been working with Catholic Charities to get settled in her new community and work toward finding a job and stable housing. Ayse does not speak English very well right now, and is working on improving her English so she can find a job. She is currently enrolled in a free ESOL class for immigrants at NYU, but the class is being held online due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Ayse will be starting her class soon and does not have a computer that she can use to join the class virtually and no income with which she could make such a large purchase. This donation will allow Ayse to attend her English classes now, and will continue to be useful in job hunting and further schooling in the future. Ayse is very grateful for any help she may receive.
