donationDescription: Orrette is a dancer and choreographer from Jamaica who fled to the U.S. last year due to the anti-LGBTQ laws in place in his home country. Orrette has been trying to launch his dance career here in New York since he arrived, and has recently begun to plan to open his own business teaching dance and choreography. In order to open and own a business, Orrette will need access to a computer and the internet, which he does not currently have. Orrette will need to launch a website for his dance school, balance budgets and keep track of records online, and create a payroll system for his business, and without a computer and online presence his business will seem less credible and have a smaller reach. Orrette already has a space in mind that he can rent as a dance studio and is working with other organizations to secure a small business loan, and this donation would allow him to really get his business up and going and be able to live out his dream of having a dance career.

donationDescription: Guadalupe is an asylee from El Salvador working as a home health aide in the Bronx. She arrived in the U.S. in 2013 after fleeing gang and personal violence in her home in El Salvador, and was finally granted asylum status in 2018. She is a single mother with two U.S. born children, a 7-year-old daughter and 1-year-old son. Guadalupe works hard to provide for her children, but living in New York is expensive and she often needs a little extra help to pay for things like clothing, school supplies, and books for her children. Guadalupe is receiving social services from Catholic Charities Refugee Resettlement program.

donationDescription: Moustafa and his nephew have just arrived to the United States after waiting 5 years in Turkey for their resettlement to be processed. Both are eager to make a good start to their new lives in Charlotte. A television will help both to learn English and stay up-to-date on what is going on in Charlotte, which is a matter of safety and community integration. Moustafa has a disability which will prevent him from working and making physical connections to the community and will hinder his ability to take in-person ESL classes. The television will be a vital way for Moustafa to learn the language and culture of his new home. In order for the clients to watch television and gain all of the benefits associated with this, they will need a television antenna. As they are not yet able to afford cable, the antenna is necessary for the television to connect to the free local HD channels.

donationDescription: Yhimkely is a refugee from Colombia who came to the U.S. in February 2021. Yhimkely traveled to New York with his wife, Jenifer, and four children to flee the violence and instability in his home region of Colombia. The family has been working with Catholic Charities and receiving social services. Yhimkely and Jenifer have been working hard to integrate into their new community in Brooklyn by learning English, setting up their home, helping their children in school, and looking for permanent work. This week, Yhimkely was hired by the MTA as a subway cleaner! He is excited to start his new job and thankful that he can support his family again. In order to stay safe at work and follow the requited dress code, Yhimkely needs to buy a pair of steel-toed construction boots to wear at work. Since he has not worked for some time during his journey to the U.S. and first few months in New York as he looked for work, Yhimkely does not have the spare income to pay for good work boots. This donation would allow Yhimkely to be safe at work and earn a necessary income to support his family.

donationDescription: Emma is an asylee who is living in the Bronx with her husband and 2 children. Emma joined her husband in New York in February 2021 as a derivative asylee after he was granted asylum. Emma is currently not working because she does not speak English and must take care of her children. She wishes to work, however, so she can bring in more money for her family and allow them to be financially stable. As Emma looks for appropriate work, she is learning to speak English. She recently enrolled in an ESOL class, but the class is held online due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Emma currently has a difficult time accessing her class and must walk to the public library to access a computer. This donation of a laptop would allow Emma to attend her ESOL classes online and learn English safely while continuing to care for her children at home. Once Emma finishes her English classes and begins to search for a job, the laptop will continue to help Emma access important resources and search for and apply to jobs online. This donation will have a great impact on the life of Emma and her family and provide years of access to online resources and information.

donationDescription: Eion is a refugee from Colombia who is living in Far Rockaway, New York and settling into his new community. Eion came to the U.S. in March 2021 and has been working with Catholic Charities to start his new life and find a job in New York. Eion is currently trying to get his GED so he can qualify for better paying jobs and hopefully pursue a college education. In order to study for and take his GED exam, Eion needs a computer that can access the internet. He is currently going to the library every time he needs to send an email, and it is a far walk for him and limits the time Eion can study, research, and respond to school and job application emails. With a laptop computer, Eion could dedicate more time to his education and improving his options in life. This donation would go a long way in allowing Eion to improve his situation in the next few years. Any help would be so appreciated.

donationDescription: Glenda is an asylee from Honduras who has been living in New York for three years. Glenda has been working as a home health aide for the past year, since she was granted asylum status in 2019, and has been living in shelters and with friends and family since she came to the U.S. Glenda has recently saved up enough money for a deposit on her very own apartment and she and her teenage daughter, Jeyssi, moved to their own apartment this month! This is a huge step for Glenda on her journey to self-sufficiency and integration into her new life in New York. She is very proud to finally have her own place to live with her daughter, but they are in need of furniture and other basics. Glenda spent almost all of her savings on renting the apartment, and could use help buying furniture and household items to fill her new home. Glenda and Jeyssi are so thankful for your consideration and any and all donations and support.

donationDescription: Johan is a 16 year old who has recently arrived from Guatemala.  His sponsor is his brother, who has a wife and a baby girl. The family is very low income and they are barely making ends meet. They owe a huge debt for their journey here, and their family back home could be in danger if it is not paid off.  Johan needs just about everything from clothes to personal hygiene products and a bed. Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Jennifer is a refugee from Colombia who came to the U.S. in February 2021. She traveled to New York with her husband and four daughters to flee the violence and instability in her home region of Colombia. The family has been working with Catholic Charities and receiving social services. Jennifer and her husband have been working hard to integrate into their new community in Brooklyn by learning English, setting up their home, helping their children in school, and looking for permanent work. Jennifer’s daughters are growing rapidly and need new shoes for the summer. When they arrived in February, the girls were all given winter boots by kind donors, but as the warm weather sets in and the girls grow, they need new shoes already. Jennifer has not yet found work and does not have the spare income to pay for good shoes for her girls. This donation would allow her to keep her children safe and comfortable.

donationDescription: Yulimar is an asylee from Venezuela who has been living with her husband and two daughters in New York while awaiting their asylum status for over a year. Yulimar and her family have been living in shelters and with friends and family since they came to the U.S., but this May Yulimar and her husband were able to move into their very own apartment for the first time since they fled Venezuela. This is a huge step for Yulimar and her family on their journey to self-sufficiency and integration into their new lives in New York. She is very proud to finally have her own place to live with her husband and two 12-year-old daughters, but they are in need of furniture and other basics to fill their new home. Yulimar spent almost all of her savings on renting the apartment, and could use help buying furniture and household items needed to turn it into a proper home for her family. Any and all donations and support will be appreciated by Yulimar and her family.

donationDescription: Yulimar is an asylee from Venezuela who has been living with her husband and two daughters in New York while awaiting their asylum status for over a year. Yulimar and her family have been living in shelters and with friends and family since they came to the U.S., but this May Yulimar and her husband were able to move into their very own apartment for the first time since they fled Venezuela. This is a huge step for Yulimar and her family on their journey to self-sufficiency and integration into their new lives in New York. She is very proud to finally have her own place to live with her husband and two 12-year-old daughters, but they are in need of furniture and other basics to fill their new home. Yulimar spent almost all of her savings on renting the apartment, and could use help buying furniture and household items needed to turn it into a proper home for her family. Any and all donations and support will be appreciated by Yulimar and her family.

donationDescription: Johan is a 16 year old who has recently arrived from Guatemala.  His sponsor is his brother, who has a wife and a baby girl. The family is very low income and they are barely making ends meet. They owe a huge debt for their journey here, and their family back home could be in danger if it is not paid off.  Johan needs just about everything from clothes to personal hygiene products and a bed. Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Aws is a refugee from Iraq who fled his homeland with his 7-year-old son and arrived in New York in February 2021. Aws and his son are now living in a room of Aws’ sister’s small apartment. His sister had moved to the U.S. a few years before he did. Aws’ son is disabled and uses a wheelchair, specialized eyeglasses, and many medications. He needs a lot of care and medical assistance. Aws is working on getting a job so he can fully provide for his son’s needs and save up money for them to eventually get an apartment of their own, but right now he does not have enough savings to provide his son for everything he needs. His son’s medication needs to be stored in a refrigerated space, and Aws is in need of a small fridge/freezer in order to store his medication. This would also allow Aws to keep their own food for himself and his son and have the opportunity to gain food independence from the family members with whom he resides. The mini fridge is not an expense Aws can afford on his own, but it would greatly improve the quality of life for himself and his son.

donationDescription: Aws is a refugee from Iraq who fled his homeland with his 7-year-old son and arrived in New York in February 2021. Aws and his son are now living in a room of Aws’ sister’s small apartment. His sister had moved to the U.S. a few years before he did. Aws’ son is disabled and uses a wheelchair, specialized eyeglasses, and many medications. He needs a lot of care and medical assistance. Aws is working on getting a job so he can fully provide for his son’s needs and save up money for them to eventually get an apartment of their own, but right now he does not have enough savings to provide  for everything his son needs. Aws’ son is not enrolled in school yet since it is almost the end of the school year, and he spends a lot of time at home in their small room of Aws’ sister’s apartment because of his mobility issues. Aws would love to get a small SMART TV so that his son could watch shows on a screen further away from him, as their shared tablet is not good for his limited vision. This would allow him to be a kid and enjoy children’s media, and to video chat with family from home on a screen he can see. A television is an expensive item Aws could not afford on his own, but it would help his son find some pleasure in his new life in New York, feel more comfortable in their room,  and help him connect with others from the safety of their room. This donation would be so appreciated by Aws and his son. Thank you for your consideration.

donationDescription: Mohamed is an asylee from Egypt who arrived in the U.S. in 2020, joining his wife and 4 children who were already living in New York. Mohamed spent much of the last year improving his English language skills and working on getting his mechanical engineering license from Egypt approved so he can work in as an engineer the U.S. Mohamed is an excellent engineer and has worked in the field for over 15 years, but he had to leave his career behind to reunite with his family. After a year of getting his credentials ready, learning English, and integrating into his new community in New York, Mohamed is ready to rejoin the workforce. He is proud to provide for his family and is eager to work again. Mohamed and his family have been surviving off their savings since he left Egypt and have very little money left for expenses. Mohamed has been offered an opportunity to apply for a job in his field working on boiler systems in manufacturing facilities, but he must take a training course from the company online before he can get the job, and he is currently unable to do that since he does not have a computer or laptop. Mohamed tried to use his family’s shared cellphone to complete the course, but it must be done on a computer. As an engineer, Mohamed will also need a computer for work if he gets the job. Mohamed does not have the money to buy himself a computer, as it would mean deciding between providing food and clothing for his children and providing for his career, and does not have enough credit in the U.S. to apply for a credit card or loan, as many refugees, asylees, and other immigrants do not. This donation would mean the world to Mohamed, his wife, and their children. It would allow Mohamed to secure the final credentials needed to get on his feet in the U.S. This computer would allow Mohamed to get a job in engineering, to work in his new job, and make money to support his family. A donation of this size would provide Mohamed with the last tool needed to be financially self-sufficient and he and his family would be forever grateful. Thank you for your consideration.

donationDescription: Abigail is a male teenager from Guatemala who recently arrived to the U.S. unaccompanied without his parents. Abigail had no choice but to leave his country due to the gang violence and poverty. His dream is to be able to live in the U.S. and enroll in school seeking a better future. He currently is in need of clothes and shoes as he has very limited resources and would like to have decent clothes prior to starting the school year. Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Alejadra is a woman in her 40s with three children and a husband who is a dairy farm worker.  Alejandra has been in the United States since she was in her 20s.  She came here following her father. She has lived on several farms in Vermont since 2009.  Alejandra has worked hard to get her driver privilege card and to learn English. All of her children attend school in Vermont.  She tries very hard to involve her children in after school activities and spends a lot of time driving them to after school sports activities like soccer and skiing.  Alejandra’s husband works 12 hour shifts with one day off every two weeks. Alejandra has been cooking for farm workers and selling her food to them for several years.  She works hard to earn some money to help support the family and give the children opportunities. After cooking and delivering food to farm workers for several years, she decided to open a taco stand at her home. On Sunday mornings in the warmer months she serves food to farm workers and the general population. She delivered food to students at Middlebury College during the pandemic. People in Addison County have come to know her food and her little taco stand is getting quite popular.  Alejandra has a small shelter where she cooks the food.  But, she does not have seating for people to eat at the taco stand.  She needs a tent, folding tables and chairs to make her venture more welcoming to the public and more successful.

donationDescription: Kpannah and her mother are refugees from Liberia living in the Bronx. Kpannah is supporting her mother and herself on her minimum wage salary and money is very tight. In January almost exactly 1 year after she was granted status in the U.S., Kpannah was able to save up enough money to start renting a very small apartment in the Bronx for herself and her mother. Her mother is elderly and disabled, and it is difficult for Kpannah to take care of her while working full-time to support them. Kpannah’s mother also wears Depends because she is immobile and must stay home alone in their apartment while Kpannah is at work. These donations of Depends pull-ups and cream will help keep her mother clean, healthy, and safe while Kpannah is at work. This donation will make a big difference in their daily lives and help the family stay healthy without the pressure and financial stress of budgeting for these important and expensive items, as they are not covered by food stamps and would be a large burden on their small budget.

donationDescription:
Kimberly recently arrived to the U.S. to reunify with her older adult sister living in Norcross, GA after 4 years of being apart. Kimberly’s older sister has been a mother figure to her and main caregiver, after their mother abandoned them when Kimberly was only 2 years old. Kimberly’s journey to the U.S. was arduous and exhausting as she is pregnant with her first child. Now that Kimberly has finally reunited with her sister, she hopes to build a better future for herself and her baby girl, who is expected to join their family on July 27th. 
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Wilson is an immigrant from Ecuador who took in his nephew, Richard, last year when Richard arrived in the U.S. as an unaccompanied minor. Richard is a 16-year-old runaway who fled violence and abuse in his home in Ecuador. When he arrived in the U.S., the ORR found his uncle, Wilson, in New York and Wilson agreed to take Richard in and sponsor him in the U.S. While still struggling himself to adjust to life as an immigrant in New York, Wilson is guiding his nephew through this difficult journey.  Richad moved into Wilson’s small one-bedroom apartment last fall and has been attending high school nearby. Wilson is proud of his nephew and happy to support him and raise him, but he often finds it difficult to make ends meet financially for their small family of 2. Wilson and Richard are working with Catholic Charities to get Richard resettled and are receiving social services. As the summer approaches, Wilson’s small apartment is becoming very warm and uncomfortable to be in. They cannot afford an air conditioner, but Wilson and Richard would be so thankful for the donation of a fan to help circulate air in their little apartment. Your donation will go a long way in keeping this family cool, safe, and comfortable this summer.

donationDescription: Ayse and her daughters, Filiz and Handan, recently joined her husband, Ahmed, in the U.S. as asylees from Turkey. Ahmed has been living in the U.S. for about two years now and has been preparing for his family to join him. He is overjoyed to be reunited with his wife and daughters. Ayse enrolled the girls in school when they arrived in New York this April, and they are now in summer school, catching up for lost time during the school year and taking extra English classes so they are ready for the new school year in the Fall. Their elder daughter, Filiz is taking summer school classes online and has been borrowing her father’s work computer and walking over a mile to the public library to do her school work. Ayse is also trying to apply for jobs online. A laptop would be such a necessary and helpful gift for this family, as it would allow Filiz to focus on her studies and access her classes more easily and let Ayse job search and learn English online. In the increasingly online world following the ongoing pandemic, technology and access to the internet are no longer a luxury, but a necessity. Ayse and Ahmed will be so grateful for any help with a device that would allow the family easier access to the internet. Thank you for your consideration.

donationDescription:
Micaela and Lucia are two teenage sisters whom recently moved to the U.S  and live with their aunt who has become their primary caregiver. Micaela and Lucia were raised by their single father who is disabled and were abandoned by their mother. Their home Country faces extreme poverty and violence; therefore, the family decided it was best for Micaela and Lucia to leave their home Country and their disabled father in order to go live with their aunt seeking better opportunities. Their aunt has accepted to take in her two nieces as her own and provide care for them. This is now a family of 8 residing in the Atlanta area. The aunt continues to work hard in order to be able to provide not just for her children but also for her two nieces. When Micaela and Lucia were asked by their caseworker if there was something they wished they had or if there was anything they needed, they stated that it would really help to have hygiene items, clothing and shoes. As these two sisters continue to adapt to a new Country, a new culture, and new language away from their father and the aunt has recently transitioned and adapting to a bigger family, it would mean the world for them to get a little bit of help with back to school clothing, shoes and hygiene items. 
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. donationDescription:
Micaela and Lucia are two teenage sisters whom recently moved to the U.S  and live with their aunt who has become their primary caregiver. Micaela and Lucia were raised by their single father who is disabled and were abandoned by their mother. Their home Country faces extreme poverty and violence; therefore, the family decided it was best for Micaela and Lucia to leave their home Country and their disabled father in order to go live with their aunt seeking better opportunities. Their aunt has accepted to take in her two nieces as her own and provide care for them. This is now a family of 8 residing in the Atlanta area. The aunt continues to work hard in order to be able to provide not just for her children but also for her two nieces. When Micaela and Lucia were asked by their caseworker if there was something they wished they had or if there was anything they needed, they stated that it would really help to have hygiene items, clothing and shoes. As these two sisters continue to adapt to a new Country, a new culture, and new language away from their father and the aunt has recently transitioned and adapting to a bigger family, it would mean the world for them to get a little bit of help with back to school clothing, shoes and hygiene items. 
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Ayse and her daughters, Filiz and Handan, recently joined her husband, Ahmed, in the U.S. as asylees from Turkey. Ahmed has been living in the U.S. for about two years now and has been preparing for his family to join him. He is overjoyed to be reunited with his wife and daughters. Ayse enrolled the girls in school when they arrived in New York this April, and they are now in summer school, catching up for lost time during the school year and taking extra English classes so they are ready for the new school year in the Fall. Their elder daughter, Filiz is taking summer school classes online and has been borrowing her father’s work computer and walking over a mile to the public library to do her school work. Ayse is also trying to apply for jobs online. A tablet would be such a necessary and helpful gift for this family, as it would allow Filiz to focus on her studies and access her classes more easily and let Ayse job search and learn English online. In the increasingly online world following the ongoing pandemic, technology and access to the internet are no longer a luxury, but a necessity. Ayse and Ahmed will be so grateful for any help with a device that would allow the family easier access to the internet. Thank you for your consideration.

donationDescription: Katherin is a 17-year-old girl from the country of Honduras who journeyed to the U.S. border to evade constant threats and physical abuse on her life. Once she arrived into the care of ORR, she gave birth to a baby boy. Katherin and her son were then placed in the care of her older brother as her sponsor, who was already living in the U.S. with his wife and their six children. Katherin moved into their apartment in Roosevelt, NY a few weeks ago. Katherine and her baby are in need of essentials, as they currently have nothing and Katherin has no form of income. Her brother and sister-in-law are currently supporting her, but they have very little extra income to begin with. Katherin is currently sleeping on the couch because the family cannot afford to buy a new bed, with a new mattress. This donation would allow Katherin the dignity of her own bed and give her a more comfortable and permanent place to sleep. Katherin hopes to enroll in high school in the fall and is focused on adjusting to her new life as a mom and a New Yorker. She is very thankful for all the help she has received since she arrived in New York.

donationDescription:
Kevin was recently reunified with his cousin, who is sponsoring him as well as another minor. The sponsor works hard to support his family, but it has been difficult to make ends meet. Welcoming another child into the home requires a lot of upfront expenses. Kevin needs basic items like clothes and bed in order to get settled into his new home, and to relieve some of the financial burden off the sponsor. 
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Marlen is a mother from Honduras who is living with her children in Queens. Her daughter, Kimberly, joined her in the U.S. as an unaccompanied minor after she was threatened by gangs in her home town in Honduras and fled for her safety. She is receiving social services from Catholic Charities in New York as she adjusts and maneuvers the justice system. Marlen has another child, a younger son, that is also living with them in their small apartment in Queens. Marlen recently lost her job when the restaurant she was working for closed due to the ongoing pandemic and is struggling to make ends meet to support her children. She is actively looking for work, but any help purchasing items her children need now would be appreciated at this time. As the school year approaches, Marlen especially needs help getting the required school supplies for her two children.

donationDescription: Angelica is an asylee from Ecuador living in Queens with her young son. She is working at a warehouse in Jamaica, Queens to support herself and her son. She is receiving social services from Catholic Charities and is taking  ESOL classes in order to improve her English so she can get a better job. She was granted asylum only recently and is still setting up her life in the U.S. Angelica was able to find a small studio apartment for herself and her son this spring and is still working on filling it with furniture and all the things they need. She has little extra money for these items, and any help would be appreciated.

donationDescription: Vivian and Juan are a married couple from Colombia who came to the U.S. to claim asylum recently. They were granted asylum earlier this summer and are now beginning their new lives in New York. They are starting completely from scratch and have almost no savings, belongings, or connections in the U.S. Vivian and Juan are receiving social services from Catholic Charities Refugee Resettlement Services, and they are very grateful for all the help they are being provided. Vivian is working as a babysitter currently to make some money, but is looking for more employment opportunities. She is also taking ESL classes to improve her English, which she hopes will enable her to qualify for a better job. Vivian was an engineer in her home country and would like to work in the engineering industry, or at least something similar, here in New York eventually. Juan is working in construction for now, but he used to work in Marketing back in Colombia and hopes to continue his marketing career in the U.S. eventually. Both Vivian and Juan are looking for more stable employment so they can improve their circumstances. In the meantime, they are struggling financially due to their long journey with asylum and would be grateful for any help with new work clothes and items for their home.

donationDescription:
Jose is newly arrived to the United States from Honduras, where he fled after his father was killed.  He is enrolled in high school, and is proud of the English he has already learned in a short time.  Jose would love to have a bicycle so he can get around on his own and have a little independence.   On a bicycle, he could easily reach the town square, as well as a grocery store and restaurants on his own. 
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Vivian and Juan are a married couple from Colombia who came to the U.S. to claim asylum recently. They were granted asylum earlier this summer and are now beginning their new lives in New York. They are starting completely from scratch and have almost no savings, belongings, or connections in the U.S. Vivian and Juan are receiving social services from Catholic Charities Refugee Resettlement Services, and they are very grateful for all the help they are being provided. Vivian is working as a babysitter currently to make some money, but is looking for more employment opportunities. She is also taking ESL classes to improve her English, which she hopes will enable her to qualify for a better job. Vivian was an engineer in her home country and would like to work in the engineering industry, or at least something similar, here in New York eventually. Juan is working in construction for now, but he used to work in Marketing back in Colombia and hopes to continue his marketing career in the U.S. eventually. Both Vivian and Juan are looking for more stable employment so they can improve their circumstances. In the meantime, they are struggling financially due to their long journey with asylum and would be grateful for any help with new work clothes and items for their home.

donationDescription: Abigail is a male teenager from Guatemala who recently arrived to the U.S. unaccompanied without his parents. Abigail had no choice but to leave his country due to the gang violence and poverty. His dream is to be able to live in the U.S. and enroll in school seeking a better future. He currently is in need of clothes and shoes as he has very limited resources and would like to have decent clothes prior to starting the school year. Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Ruby and her partner moved to our area a few months ago. Ruby is currently 39 weeks pregnant and is sleeping on the floor. Her partner works in the restaurant industry and is making enough to pay for rent and thankfully their housing situation is stable. She has been participating in the Healthy Start Program and has learned a lot about what to expect of the pregnancy and much more. As a couple, they have faced many barriers due to the lack of cultural competency among some of our local organizations. At this moment they are safe, excited, and getting ready to bring a baby home soon. It is amazing to to encounter people that never complain about their circumstances. They are thankful for having a roof over their head and a job to go to. It would be even better if they had a bed to sleep on. Thanks!

donationDescription: Ruby and her partner moved to our area a few months ago. Ruby is currently 39 weeks pregnant and is sleeping on the floor. Her partner works in the restaurant industry and is making enough to pay for rent and thankfully their housing situation is stable. She has been participating in the Healthy Start Program and has learned a lot about what to expect of the pregnancy and much more. As a couple, they have faced many barriers due to the lack of cultural competency among some of our local organizations. At this moment they are safe, excited, and getting ready to bring a baby home soon. It is amazing to to encounter people that never complain about their circumstances. They are thankful for having a roof over their head and a job to go to. It would be even better if they had a bed to sleep on. Thanks!

donationDescription: Over recently moved to the U.S. to reside with his mom, his little brother, and step-father after being separated for about two years. Bessy is a homemaker and stays at home to provide full time supervision to her youngest son, who  was born prematurely along with having vision and hearing deficits; he is largely non-verbal and gets sick easily. Bessy is often visiting hospitals to follow-up with medical care needed for her youngest child. The family only has one income, from Bessy’s partner, and is enough to cover living expenses and medical care for the youngest child. With limited financial resources, the family is saving-up to provide Over with wish list items. Over has stated how much he enjoys sports—boxing is his favorite sport! Over unfortunately fractured his foot earlier this year, and was unable to be as active as he would like due to recovery time. He hopes to one day be able to enroll in boxing classes to stay active doing what he loves. He enjoys spending his time outside playing with friends!   Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Edson is from Guatemala, and arrived to the US earlier this year to reunify with his father.  After arriving, he learned that his grandfather back home had been beaten and robbed.  He suffered from a broken shoulder, bruised ribs, and other injuries.  His grandfather relies on Edson's father for financial support, and now needs additional medical treatment that they are struggling to afford.   Additionally, Edson's father has court in two months and is trying to fund legal representation and transportation to court which is more than four hours away. The family would deeply appreciate any financial assistance possible to send home for medical treatment for Edson's grandfather, as well as help related to the upcoming court date.  Walmart gift cards are being requested to fund every day expenses like groceries so that money can be saved to pay for medical and legal expenses. Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription: Jose is a 14-year-old boy from El Salvador.  He and his family need winter jackets.  Jose recently told his caseworker, “I am happy to live with my mom again. I hope that one day I can study to become a lawyer so I can help people in the same situation as me. My siblings live in El Salvador and I hope one day I can help them. My dream is to have my family reunited. For now, I want to go to school soon!”  Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription:
Recently, a Safe Passages caseworker in Texas was assigned to the case of a teenager released from a shelter near the border. The teen is reluctant to share any personal information with the caseworker. It has been difficult to provide essential services due to the lack of trust. The caseworker hopes this gift card for clothing and other personal items will demonstrate their intent to be helpful to the client.
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

Recently, a Safe Passages caseworker in Texas was assigned to the case of a teenager released from a shelter near the border. Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. donationDescription:
Carlos recently arrived in the U.S. to reunite with his mom and 5 siblings after being separated for over 7 years. His mom has been working to provide for all of her kids and has the support of her partner. However, their income is limited given that mom is only able to work part-time as she needs to provide care for the children after school, and her partner is currently facing decreased work hours. The family had been trying to save up to purchase a bed for Carlos, but due to the instability of the work hours from her partner, they have had to prioritize other basic needs such as food and utilities. At this time Carlos is sharing a bed with his sibling, but a donation of a twin mattress would truly impact this family. 

Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription:
Edgar left his home country of Guatemala because there was a hurricane that devastated his hometown. After the hurricane, Edgar said his family was left with nothing. Edgar could no longer attend school because his family faced financial difficulties. Edgar told his family he wanted to come to the United States to live with his cousin because he wants to finish his studies and eventually send money back to his family. Edgar is adjusting well to his new life but with some difficulties. Edgar and his cousin rent out a room in an apartment. Edgar has noticed that his cousin works very hard in construction and sometimes the pay is not enough to cover all their expenses. Edgar’s cousin wants him to focus on school and not worry about anything else. But for Edgar, it is difficult to ignore his cousin’s efforts. Edgar recently said: “I am grateful for my cousin’s help but sometimes I feel like a burden because he has done a lot for me. I want to help but I am too young and not allowed to work. I need to go to school. Maybe in the future, I can pay him back for all he has done to help me and my family.” 

Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription:
Esmeralda and Eliseo are siblings, they traveled alone all the way from El Salvador because they wanted to be reunited with their mother. Esmeralda and Eliseo were under the care of an uncle who was not very nice to them and they have been through very difficult times. Their mom, Lili, has felt a lot of anguish being separated from her children. Being reunited with her adored children is the only thing she prays for. While the children waited to be reunited with their mom, Eliseo wrote letters for his mom and made drawings for her. Esmeralda is the oldest and when Eliseo feels a bit sad, she cheers him up by telling him that soon they will be able to hug their mom and they will never be separated again. The children’s mom, Lili, wants to buy a bed for each child, but it is very costly. All they need is two, small, single beds for the children to have the sweetest dreams.  
Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

donationDescription:
Edgar left his home country of Guatemala because there was a hurricane that devastated his hometown. After the hurricane, Edgar said his family was left with nothing. Edgar could no longer attend school because his family faced financial difficulties. Edgar told his family he wanted to come to the United States to live with his cousin because he wants to finish his studies and eventually send money back to his family. Edgar is adjusting well to his new life but with some difficulties. Edgar and his cousin rent out a room in an apartment. Edgar has noticed that his cousin works very hard in construction and sometimes the pay is not enough to cover all their expenses. Edgar’s cousin wants him to focus on school and not worry about anything else. But for Edgar it is difficult to ignore his cousin’s efforts. Edgar recently said:“I am grateful for my cousin’s help but sometimes I feel like a burden because he has done a lot for me. I want to help but I am too young and not allowed to work. I need to go to school. Maybe in the future, I can pay him back for all he has done to help me and my family.” 

Unaccompanied children served by Catholic Charities Atlanta are children who cross our borders and have no parent or legal guardian who is available to provide for their care and physical custody. For a limited number of Unaccompanied Children, the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement funds home studies and post-release services by social services providers to help ensure children are released into safe placements and to facilitate family and community integration after reunification.

I am in the legal process of seeking asylum in the US.  My three children are still in Africa, and I support them. Since I was a little girl my dream was to become a doctor, but where I grew up, women were expected to take care of the family at home. I could not achieve that dream there.  When I came to America I saw the opportunity to go back to school and become a skilled healthcare worker so I could support myself and my family.    

I’m finishing my first year in the radiology program at River Valley Community College in Claremont, NH, and it has been going well. The classes are hard, but I study hard.   I use a car to get to classes and the clinicals. Coming home from school one very icy night, another driver rear-ended my car, and it was totaled.  I was fortunately not injured!  

Right now, I cannot afford to buy a car. Friends are helping me get to classes and the clinicals temporarily, but I cannot depend on them forever.  I do not want to have to drop out of the school program for lack of transportation!

After all the hardships of my life in Africa, going to school and being able to support my children makes me really proud of myself, but  I need some help. A car donation from you will allow me to achieve my goal to become a radiologic technician. I’ll be an example for my kids and the first woman in my family to become a healthcare professional. Thank you.

I will greatly appreciate your donation. (Original amt $4600)
